awd_titl_txt: An Integrated STEM Approach for Studying Aerospace Engineering Design and Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project at the University of California-Davis will develop an aerospace engineering course to significantly address contemporary needs within the engineering industry.  The course is designed to help undergraduate mechanical and aerospace engineering students understand how airplanes fly by taking them through the process of designing, modeling, manufacturing, and testing a prototype wing.  The combination of design, manufacturing, and experimental validation will constitute an educational concept for undergraduate students in engineering, integrating important topics such as physics of flight and manufacturing processes, including sustainability.  The contexts of flight and sustainability allow for student engagement, while presenting substantial opportunities for intellectual growth.

The goal of this effort is to research simple and effective methods for teaching aerospace engineering design and manufacturing concepts and fundamentals to college students, through the use of computer simulations, manufacturing and laboratory experiments.  The course takes an active, project-based approach that research shows is effective in fostering the development of deep, conceptual learning and, in turn, greater problem solving flexibility in engineering.  Course and project evaluation will include (1) assessing student learning through classroom examinations; (2) assessing student perceptions using the intrinsic value subscale, engineering design self-efficacy, and adaptive expertise and (3) "scenario-based" assessment to evaluate the benefits of the interdisciplinary nature of the instruction. The design documents, course modules, and assessment materials will be published and made available to other teaching institutions so this unique teaching concept can be applied and can lead to transformative teaching of aerospace engineering design and manufacturing. The design documents will be available to educational institutes as well as to industry so teaching and research in these communities can benefit from this effort.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop simple and effective methods for teaching college students the fundamental concepts of aerospace design and manufacturing. For this goal, the project established physical test setups with stationary and inclined water tables, airfoil and nozzle models, a water height measurement system, a quick-release system for the models, and wave pattern recordings. The design information on all experimental setups are available upon request.

A syllabus, curriculum and teaching materials for a new course EME 198 Design & Manufacturing of Nozzle and Airfoil Shapes for Compressible Flow Visualization were developed. These materials include computational results, discussions of industrial product design, sustainable manufacturing principles, product quality, shallow water theory, and compressible flow theory and were also reported in several publications. Student learning assessment materials in the form of written assignments, course evaluations, surveys, and scenario–based assessment were developed and analyzed.

The project involved 3 faculty members, 12 graduate students, and 23 undergraduate students over the project period. In addition, the newly developed class was taught to 36 students in Spring 2017 at UC Davis. Additionally, 8 first-year seminars on computer simulations for STEM education, an undergraduate course on basic mathematical techniques for science and engineering students, and three COSMOS (California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science) modules were for high-school students were taught.

The development of this project was documented through a public website, three journal papers, four conference papers, two conference posters, and several more papers in preparation. Several presentations on the project have been made including at the 2016 EnFuse (Envisioning the Future of Undergraduate STEM Education) Research and Practice Symposium; the ASME International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC) 2016 and 2018; the 2017 North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC 45); the 2017 American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Conference, and the International Conference on Computational Fluid Dynamics (ICCFD10) in 2018. Moreover, an I-corps L project on a simplified water table explored potential customer segments in Summer 2016.
